text:
The **economy of Ghana** has a diverse and rich resource base, including the
manufacturing and export of digital technology goods, automotive and ship
construction and export, and the export of resources such as hydrocarbons and
industrial minerals. Record high Gold price 2023 earned Ghana 15.6 billion $
of exports.

The Ghanaian domestic economy in 2012 revolved around services, which
accounted for 50% of GDP and employed 28% of the work force. Besides the
industrialization associated with minerals and oil, industrial development in
Ghana remains basic, often associated with plastics (such as chairs, plastic
bags, razors, and pens). 53.6% of Ghana's workforce were employed in
agriculture in 2013.[_outdated statistic_]

Ghana embarked on a currency re-denomination exercise from the Cedi (₵) to the
new currency, Ghana Cedi (GH₵) in July 2007. The transfer rate is 1 Ghana Cedi
for every 10,000 Cedis.

Ghana became the largest gold-producing country in Africa after overtaking
South Africa in 2019. The country is also the second-largest cocoa producer
(after Ivory Coast). Ghana is rich in diamonds,  manganese or manganese ore,
bauxite, and oil. Most of its debt was cancelled in 2005, but government
spending was later allowed to balloon. Coupled with a plunge in oil prices,
this led to an economic crisis that forced the government to negotiate a $920
million extended credit facility from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in
April 2015. Bloomberg rated Ghana currency Cedi as the strongest performing
currency in the World April 2025 against the Dollar reducing its debt burden.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Ghana is characterized by a diverse and resource-rich profile, including manufacturing and export of digital technology goods, automotive and ship construction, and the export of resources such as hydrocarbons and industrial minerals.
• In 2023, Ghana earned approximately 15.6 billion USD from record-high gold prices, highlighting the significance of gold exports to its economy.
• In 2012, Ghana’s domestic economy was predominantly service-oriented, with services accounting for 50% of GDP and employing 28% of the workforce.

• Industrial development in Ghana remains basic, primarily associated with the processing of plastics into products such as chairs, plastic bags, razors, and pens, despite efforts toward industrialization linked to minerals and oil.
• As of 2013, approximately 53.6% of Ghana’s workforce was employed in agriculture, though this statistic is considered outdated.
• In July 2007, Ghana undertook a currency re-denomination exercise, transitioning from the Cedi (₵) to the new Ghana Cedi (GH₵), with a transfer rate of 1 Ghana Cedi for every 10,000 old Cedis.
• Ghana became the largest gold-producing country in Africa in 2019, surpassing South Africa in gold output.
• The country is the second-largest cocoa producer globally, after Ivory Coast.
• Ghana possesses significant mineral resources, including diamonds, manganese (or manganese ore), bauxite, and oil.
• Most of Ghana’s external debt was canceled in 2005; however, subsequent government spending increased substantially, contributing to economic instability.

• A decline in oil prices and increased government expenditure led to an economic crisis, prompting Ghana to negotiate a $920 million extended credit facility with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in April 2015.
• In April 2025, Bloomberg rated the Ghanaian Cedi as the strongest performing currency in the world against the US dollar, which contributed to a reduction in Ghana’s debt burden.

text:
Value-added tax is a consumption tax administered in Ghana. The tax regime
that started in 1998 had a single rate but since September 2007 entered into a
multiple rate regime. In 1998, the rate of tax was 10% and amended in 2000 to
12.5%. The top income tax and corporate tax rates are 25%. Other taxes
included with value-added tax (VAT), are the national health insurance levy,
and a capital gains tax. The overall tax burden was 12.1% of Ghana's total
domestic income in 2013. Ghana's national budget was the equivalent of 39.8%
of GDP in 2013. Ghana is implementing the rent tax in 2021.
openai_summarised_points: • Value-added tax (VAT) in Ghana is a consumption tax administered at the national level.
• The VAT regime in Ghana commenced in 1998 with a single rate structure.
• Since September 2007, Ghana's VAT system transitioned into a multiple rate regime, allowing for different rates on various goods and services.
• The VAT rate was initially set at 10% in 1998.
• The VAT rate was amended in 2000 to 12.5%.
• The highest income tax and corporate tax rates in Ghana are both set at 25%.
• Additional taxes accompanying VAT include the national health insurance levy and a capital gains tax.
• In 2013, Ghana's overall tax burden was calculated at 12.1% of the country's total domestic income.
• Ghana's national budget in 2013 was equivalent to 39.8% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Ghana began implementing a rent tax in the year 2021.

text:
Ghana's industrial base is relatively advanced. Import-substitution industries
include electronics manufacturing. Rlg Communications is the first indigenous
African company to assemble laptops, desktops, and mobile phones, and is West
Africa's biggest information and communications technology (ICT) and mobile
phone manufacturing company.

Ghana began its automotive industry with the construction of a prototype
robust SUV, named the SMATI Turtle 1, intended for use in the rough African
terrain. It was designed and manufactured by the Artisans of Suame Magazine
Industrial Development Organization. Urban electric cars have been
manufactured in Ghana since 2014.

As of 2012 there were four major companies in the textiles sector: Akosombo
Textiles Limited, Tex Style Ghana Limited, Printex Ghana, and Ghana Textile
Manufacturing Company.

Ghana National Petroleum Corporation and Ghana Oil Company deal with crude oil
and gas exploration, exploitation, and refining.
openai_summarised_points: • Ghana's industrial base is relatively advanced compared to other West African nations, with notable activities in import-substitution industries, including electronics manufacturing.

• Rlg Communications is recognized as the first indigenous African company to assemble laptops, desktops, and mobile phones, and it is the largest ICT and mobile phone manufacturing company in West Africa.

• Ghana initiated its automotive industry with the development of a prototype robust SUV named the SMATI Turtle 1, designed for rugged African terrains; this vehicle was constructed by the Artisans of Suame Magazine Industrial Development Organization.
• Since 2014, Ghana has been manufacturing urban electric cars, indicating a move toward sustainable and innovative transportation solutions.
• As of 2012, the textiles sector in Ghana comprised four major companies: Akosombo Textiles Limited, Tex Style Ghana Limited, Printex Ghana, and Ghana Textile Manufacturing Company.

• The Ghana National Petroleum Corporation (GNPC) and Ghana Oil Company (GOIL) are the primary organizations involved in crude oil and gas exploration, exploitation, and refining activities within the country.

At the end of January 2022, total number of voice subscription in Ghana stood
at 41,380,751.This represents a percentage increase of 1.28% over December
2019 figures of 40,857,007. The total penetration rate stands at 136.79%.

The mass media of Ghana is among the most liberal in Africa, with Ghana

worldwide press freedom index. Chapter 12 of the Constitution of Ghana
guarantees freedom of the Ghanaian press and the independence of the mass
media, and Chapter 2 prohibits censorship. Ghanaian press freedom was restored
in 1992.

Ghana was one of the first countries in Africa to achieve the connection to
the World Wide Web. In 2010, there were 165 licensed internet service
providers in Ghana and they were running 29 of the fiber optic, and authorized
networks VSAT operators were 176, of which 57 functioned, and 99 internet

openai_summarised_points: • As of the end of January 2022, Ghana's total number of voice subscriptions was 41,380,751, representing a 1.28% increase compared to December 2019, when subscriptions numbered 40,857,007.
• The overall mobile telecommunication penetration rate in Ghana stood at 136.79%.
• Competition among mobile-phone companies significantly contributes to the growth of Ghana's telecommunications industry.
• The market leader is MTN, with 23,150,485 voice subscriptions, accounting for 55.95% of the market share.
• Vodafone follows as the second-largest provider, with 9,075,795 voice subscriptions, representing 21.93% of the market share.
• AirtelTigo has 8,428,322 voice subscriptions, making up 20.69% of the market share.
• Glo's voice subscriptions total 726,149, which constitute approximately 1.75% of the market share.
• Ghana's mass media is among the most liberal in Africa, ranking as the third-freest on the continent and 30th globally on the worldwide press freedom index.
• The Ghanaian Constitution, specifically Chapter 12, guarantees freedom of the press and the independence of the mass media, while Chapter 2 prohibits censorship.
• Press freedom in Ghana was restored in 1992 after a period of restrictions.
• Ghana was among the first African countries to connect to the World Wide Web.
• In 2010, Ghana had 165 licensed internet service providers (ISPs).
• These ISPs operated 29 fiber optic networks, and authorized VSAT (Very Small Aperture Terminal) networks numbered 176, of which 57 were operational.
• There were 99 internet operators authorized to serve the public.
• Private data and packet-switched network operators totaled 25.
• The change in per capita GDP of Ghana from 1870 to 2018 has been documented, with figures adjusted for inflation to 2011 International dollars, illustrating long-term economic trends.
• The share of Ghana's population living in extreme poverty has been tracked over time from 1981 to 2019, indicating shifts in poverty levels within the country.

• A comprehensive table presents key economic indicators for Ghana spanning the years 1980 to 2023, including GDP in both PPP and nominal terms, GDP per capita, real GDP growth, inflation rates, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.

• In 1980, Ghana's GDP was valued at 12.8 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 1,202 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 37.4 billion US dollars; the economy experienced a minimal growth rate of 0.4%, and government debt was not available.

• During the early 1980s, Ghana's economy faced significant challenges, with GDP peaking at 13.5 billion US dollars (PPP) in 1981, but experiencing negative growth of −3.5%, and a dramatic increase in government debt to 116.5% of GDP in 1981.

• From 1982 to 1987, Ghana's GDP in PPP terms gradually increased from 13.2 billion to 18.9 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita rising from 1,175 to 1,439 US dollars, and inflation rates fluctuating between −6.9% and 5.6%.
• In 1984, inflation spiked to 9.0%, and government debt was at 40.0%, reflecting economic instability; by 1985, inflation decreased to 5.1%, and government debt reduced to 10.3%.
• The late 1980s saw continued growth, with GDP in PPP reaching 20.9 billion US dollars in 1988, and GDP per capita increasing to 1,550 US dollars; inflation remained relatively high at 5.6%.

• The 1990s marked a period of economic recovery and growth, with GDP rising from 24.4 billion US dollars in 1990 to 36.3 billion in 1996, and GDP per capita increasing from 1,728 to 2,228 US dollars.
• Notable fluctuations include the 1990 GDP growth rate of 3.3%, and a peak inflation rate of 5.8% in 1997; government debt as a percentage of GDP decreased from 37.2% in 1990 to 46.0% in 1996.

• The early 2000s saw steady economic expansion, with GDP in PPP reaching 66.8 billion US dollars in 2005, and GDP per capita rising to 3,126 US dollars; inflation remained below 6% during most years.

• From 2006 onwards, Ghana experienced accelerated growth, with GDP in PPP increasing from 72.9 billion US dollars in 2006 to 149.0 billion in 2017, and GDP per capita rising from 3,331 to 5,148 US dollars.
• In 2008, inflation peaked at 9.2%, but generally remained below 6% from 2010 to 2018, with notable exceptions such as 14.0% in 2011 and 15.5% in 2014.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP fluctuated, reaching a high of 80.2% in 2000, then decreasing to 18.5% in 2006, before rising again to 62.0% in 2018.
• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a slowdown, with GDP growth dropping to 0.5%, inflation at 0.5%, and government debt increasing to 72.3% of GDP.
• Post-pandemic recovery is evident with GDP in PPP reaching 196.4 billion US dollars in 2021, and GDP per capita increasing to 6,256 US dollars; inflation was 5.1%.
• In 2022, Ghana's GDP in PPP terms grew to 216.6 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita at 6,752 US dollars, and inflation at 3.1%; government debt rose sharply to 92.4% of GDP.

• By 2023, Ghana's GDP in PPP was 227.2 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita at 6,905 US dollars, inflation at 1.2%, and government debt at 84.9% of GDP, indicating ongoing economic growth and relative price stability.

Ghana's top export products in 2016 were crude petroleum ($2.66B), gold
($2.39B), cocoa beans ($2.27B), cocoa paste ($382M) and cocoa butter ($252M).
Ghana's top export destinations in 2016 were Switzerland ($1.73B), China
($1.06B), France ($939M), India ($789M) and the Netherlands ($778M).

Ghana's top import categories in 2016 were refined petroleum ($2.18B), crude
petroleum ($546M), gold ($428M), rice ($328M) and packaged medicaments
($297M). The nations with the highest value of imports to Ghana in 2016 were
China ($4.1B), the Netherlands ($1.58B), the United States ($1.1B), Nigeria
($920M) and India ($668M).

• The primary destinations for Ghana's exports in 2016 were Switzerland, receiving $1.73 billion worth of goods; China with $1.06 billion; France at $939 million; India at $789 million; and the Netherlands with $778 million.

text:
The financial services in Ghana have seen a lot of reforms in the past years.
The Banking (Amendment) Act 2007 included the awarding of a general banking
license to qualified banks, which allows only indigenous Ghana offshore banks
to operate in Ghana. Indigenous Ghana private bank Capital Bank was the first
to be awarded the general banking license in Ghana as well as indigenous Ghana
private banks UniBank, National Investment Bank and Prudential Bank Limited.
It has therefore become possible for Ghanaian non-resident individuals or
residents and foreign companies or indigenous Ghana companies to open
indigenous Ghana offshore bank accounts in Ghana. Indigenous Ghana retail and
savings banks include Agricultural Development Bank of Ghana, CAL Bank, GCB
Bank Ltd, Home Finance Company and UT Bank as well as indigenous Ghana savings
and loan institutions ABii National and Savings and Loans Company.
openai_summarised_points: • The financial services sector in Ghana has experienced significant reforms over recent years, reflecting ongoing efforts to modernize and regulate the industry.
• The Banking (Amendment) Act of 2007 was a key legislative development that introduced the concept of a general banking license, which could be awarded to qualified banks operating within Ghana.
• This amendment specifically allows only indigenous Ghana offshore banks to operate in Ghana under the general banking license framework.
• Capital Bank, an indigenous Ghanaian private bank, was the first to be awarded a general banking license under this new regulatory regime.
• Other indigenous Ghana private banks that received the general banking license include UniBank, National Investment Bank, and Prudential Bank Limited.
• The reform has enabled Ghanaian non-resident individuals, residents, foreign companies, and indigenous Ghanaian companies to open indigenous Ghana offshore bank accounts within Ghana.
• Indigenous Ghana retail and savings banks include the Agricultural Development Bank of Ghana, CAL Bank, GCB Bank Ltd, Home Finance Company, and UT Bank.
• Additionally, indigenous Ghanaian savings and loan institutions such as ABii National and the Savings and Loans Company are part of the domestic banking landscape.

text:
Ghana discovered significant reserves of oil and natural gas offshore
throughout the 2000s and 2010s. The country officially became an oil & gas
producer in 2010 with the commissioning of the Jubilee field by Tullow Oil and
currently produces from three major offshore hubs: Jubilee, TEN, and OCTP. In
2021, its production stood at some 150,000 barrels of oil per day (bopd).
Since production began in 2010 Ghana has rose to be the 34th largest national
producer of oil.

In 2021 Ghana exported more than 71mil barrels of oil. China was the largest
importer of Ghana oil, receiving over 41% of exports with South Africa, the
second largest importer, taking 13.9%.
openai_summarised_points: • Ghana discovered significant reserves of oil and natural gas offshore during the 2000s and 2010s, marking a major development in its energy sector.
• The country officially commenced oil and gas production in 2010 with the commissioning of the Jubilee field, which was developed by Tullow Oil.
• Ghana currently produces oil from three major offshore hubs: Jubilee, TEN (Tweneboa, Enyenra, and Atuah), and OCTP (Offshore Cape Three Points).
• In 2021, Ghana’s oil production was approximately 150,000 barrels of oil per day (bopd).
• Since the start of production in 2010, Ghana has risen to become the 34th largest national producer of oil globally.
• In 2021, Ghana exported over 71 million barrels of oil.
• China was the largest importer of Ghanaian oil in 2021, accounting for over 41% of Ghana’s oil exports.
• South Africa was the second-largest importer, receiving 13.9% of Ghana’s oil exports.

text:
Wind turbines on a wind farm

Ghana has Class 4–6 wind resources and high-wind locations, such as Nkwanta,
the Accra Plains, and Kwahu and Gambaga mountains. The maximum energy that
could be tapped from Ghana's available wind resource for electricity is
estimated to be about 500–600 GWh/year. To give perspective: in 2011, per the
same Energy Commission, the largest Akosombo hydroelectric dam in Ghana alone
produced 6,495 GWh of electric power and, counting all Ghana's geothermal
energy production in addition, the total energy generated was 11,200 GWh in
that year. These assessments do not take into consideration further limiting
factors such as land-use restrictions, the existing grid (or how far the wind
resource may be from the grid) and accessibility.
openai_summarised_points: • Ghana possesses wind resources classified as Class 4–6, indicating moderate to high wind energy potential.
• High-wind locations in Ghana include Nkwanta, the Accra Plains, and the Kwahu and Gambaga mountains.
• The maximum extractable energy from Ghana’s wind resources for electricity generation is estimated to be approximately 500–600 GWh per year.
• In 2011, the Akosombo hydroelectric dam in Ghana alone produced 6,495 GWh of electricity, serving as a significant benchmark for renewable energy output in the country.
• The total energy generated in Ghana in 2011, including all geothermal sources, was 11,200 GWh.

• The assessments of wind energy potential do not account for several limiting factors, such as land-use restrictions, the existing electrical grid infrastructure, the distance of wind resources from the grid, and accessibility issues.

text:
Hybrid sorghum plantation field

Ghana has put in place mechanisms to attract investments into its biomass and
bio-energy sectors to stimulate rural development, create jobs and save
foreign exchange. Main investments in the bio-energy subsector existed in the
areas of production, are transportation, storage, distribution, sale,
marketing and exportation.

The goal of Ghana regarding bio-energy, as articulated by its energy sector
policy, is to modernize and examine the benefits of bio-energy on a
sustainable basis. Biomass is Ghana's dominant energy resource in terms of
endowment and consumption, with the two primary bio-fuels consumed being
ethanol and biodiesel. To that effect, the Ghana ministry of Energy in 2010
developed its energy sector strategy and development plan. Highlights of the
strategy include sustaining the supply and efficient use of wood fuels while
ensuring that their utilization does not lead to deforestation.

The plan would support private sector investments in the cultivation of bio-
fuel feedstock, the extraction of bio-oil, and refining it into secondary
products, thereby creating financial and tax incentives. The Ghana Renewal
Energy Act provides the necessary fiscal incentives for renewable energy
development by the private sector, and also details the control and management
of bio-fuel and wood fuel projects in Ghana. The Ghana National Petroleum
Authority (NPA) was tasked by the Renewable Energy Act 2011 to price Ghana's
bio-fuel blend in accordance with the prescribed petroleum pricing formula.

The combined effects of climate change and global economic turbulence had
triggered a sense of urgency among Ghanaian policymakers, industry and
development practitioners to find sustainable and viable solutions in the area
of bio-fuels.

Brazil, which makes ethanol from maize and sugarcane, is currently the world's
largest bio-fuel market.
openai_summarised_points: • Ghana has established mechanisms aimed at attracting investments into its biomass and bio-energy sectors to promote rural development, generate employment, and conserve foreign exchange reserves.
• The primary areas of investment within Ghana’s bio-energy subsector include production, transportation, storage, distribution, sale, marketing, and exportation activities.
• The overarching goal of Ghana’s bio-energy policy, as articulated by its energy sector strategy, is to modernize the sector and evaluate the benefits of bio-energy on a sustainable basis.
• Biomass is Ghana’s most abundant and widely consumed energy resource, with ethanol and biodiesel being the two main bio-fuels utilized.
• In 2010, the Ghana Ministry of Energy developed a comprehensive energy sector strategy and development plan to support bio-energy initiatives.
• Key highlights of this strategy include maintaining a sustainable supply and efficient use of wood fuels while preventing deforestation caused by their utilization.
• The strategy aims to encourage private sector investments in cultivating bio-fuel feedstock, extracting bio-oil, and refining it into secondary products, supported by financial and tax incentives.

• The Ghana Renewable Energy Act provides fiscal incentives to promote renewable energy development by the private sector and establishes regulations for the control and management of bio-fuel and wood fuel projects in Ghana.
• The Ghana National Petroleum Authority (NPA) was mandated by the Renewable Energy Act of 2011 to set bio-fuel blend prices in accordance with the prescribed petroleum pricing formula.

• Climate change impacts and global economic instability have heightened the urgency among Ghanaian policymakers, industry stakeholders, and development practitioners to identify sustainable and viable bio-fuel solutions.
• Brazil is recognized as the world’s largest bio-fuel market, producing ethanol primarily from maize and sugarcane.

Ghana's increasing oil exports as a percentage of all exports

• The country’s oil exports have been increasing as a proportion of total exports, indicating a growing role of hydrocarbon revenues in Ghana’s economy.

• Mining has become increasingly important to Ghana’s economy since the early 2000s, experiencing an approximate growth rate of 30% in 2007.
• The primary minerals extracted in Ghana include bauxite, gold—of which Ghana is one of the world's largest producers—and phosphates.

text:
Tourism destinations in Ghana

The Ministry of Tourism has placed great emphasis upon further tourism support
and development. Tourism contributed to 4.9% of GDP in 2009, attracting around
500,000 visitors. Tourist destinations include Ghana's many castles and forts,
national parks, beaches, nature reserves, landscapes and World Heritage
buildings and sites.

In 2011, _Forbes_ magazine ranked Ghana eleventh-friendliest country in the
world. The assertion was based on a survey of a cross-section of travelers in
2010. Of all the countries on the African continent that were included in the
survey, Ghana ranked highest.

To enter Ghana, it is necessary to have a visa authorized by the Government of
Ghana, except for certain entrepreneurs on business trips.
openai_summarised_points: • The Ministry of Tourism in Ghana has prioritized enhancing tourism support and development initiatives to boost the sector's growth.
• In 2009, tourism contributed approximately 4.9% to Ghana's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• During the same year, Ghana attracted around 500,000 international visitors to its various tourist sites.
• Key tourist destinations in Ghana include numerous historical castles and forts, which are significant for their cultural and historical value.
• Other major attractions encompass national parks, beaches, nature reserves, diverse landscapes, and UNESCO World Heritage sites and buildings.
• In 2011, Forbes magazine ranked Ghana as the eleventh-friendliest country in the world, based on a survey conducted in 2010 involving a diverse group of travelers.
• Ghana was the highest-ranked country on the African continent in Forbes' friendliness survey.

In 2013 agriculture employed 53.6% of Ghana's total labor force. Agribusiness
accounts for a small fraction of the gross domestic product. The main
harvested crops are corn, plantain, rice, millet, sorghum, cassava and yam.
Unlike the agricultural livestock, forestry and fishing sectors, the crop
sector is key to the Ghanaian agricultural industry.

Ghana produced in 2018:

* 20.8 million tons of cassava (4th largest producer in the world, second only to Nigeria, Thailand and Congo)
* 7.8 million tonnes of yam (2nd largest producer in the world, second only to Nigeria)
* 4.1 million tons of plantain (2nd largest producer in the world, just behind Congo)
* 2.6 million tons of palm oil (8th largest producer in the world)
* 2.3 million tons of maize
* 1.4 million tons of taro (4th largest producer in the world, second only to Nigeria, China and Cameroon)
* 947 thousand tons of cocoa (2nd largest producer in the world, second only to Ivory Coast)
* 769 thousand tons of rice
* 753 thousand tons of orange (19th largest producer in the world)
* 713 thousand tons of pineapple (11th largest producer in the world)
* 521 thousand tons of peanut

In addition to smaller productions of other agricultural products, like sweet
potato (151 thousand tons), natural rubber (23 thousand tons) and tobacco (2.3
thousand tons).
openai_summarised_points: • In 2013, agriculture employed 53.6% of Ghana's total labor force, indicating its significant role in the country's employment landscape.
• Agribusiness contributes only a small fraction to Ghana's gross domestic product (GDP), suggesting that the sector's economic impact is relatively limited compared to other industries.
• The primary harvested crops in Ghana include corn, plantain, rice, millet, sorghum, cassava, and yam, which are central to the country's agricultural output.
• Unlike the livestock, forestry, and fishing sectors, the crop sector is considered the key component of the Ghanaian agricultural industry, emphasizing its importance in national agriculture.
• In 2018, Ghana produced approximately 20.8 million tons of cassava, making it the 4th largest producer globally, following Nigeria, Thailand, and Congo.
• Ghana produced about 7.8 million tonnes of yam in 2018, ranking as the 2nd largest producer in the world, behind Nigeria.
• The country produced roughly 4.1 million tons of plantain in 2018, also the 2nd largest globally, just behind Congo.
• Ghana's palm oil production in 2018 reached 2.6 million tons, placing it as the 8th largest producer worldwide.
• The maize (corn) production in 2018 was approximately 2.3 million tons.
• Ghana produced about 1.4 million tons of taro in 2018, ranking as the 4th largest producer globally, after Nigeria, China, and Cameroon.
• Cocoa production in 2018 was approximately 947 thousand tons, making Ghana the 2nd largest producer in the world, after Ivory Coast.
• The country produced around 769 thousand tons of rice in 2018.
• Ghana's orange production in 2018 was about 753 thousand tons, ranking 19th in the world.
• Pineapple production in 2018 was approximately 713 thousand tons, placing Ghana as the 11th largest producer globally.
• The country produced roughly 521 thousand tons of peanuts in 2018.
• Smaller-scale productions include sweet potato with 151 thousand tons, natural rubber with 23 thousand tons, and tobacco with 2.3 thousand tons.

The judicial system of Ghana deals with corruption, economic malpractice and
lack of economic transparency. Despite significant economic progress,
obstacles do remain. Particular institutions need reform, and property rights
need improvement. The overall investment regime lacks market transparency.
Tackling these issues will be necessary if Ghana's rapid economic growth is to
be maintained.

According to Transparency International's 2022 Corruption Perception Index,
Ghana was ranked 72nd out of 180 countries, with a score of 43 on a scale
where a 0–9 score means highly corrupt, and a 90–100 score means very clean.
This was based on perceived levels of public sector corruption. John Addo
Kufuor, son of former President John Agyekum Kufuor and Kojo Annan, son of
former Secretary-General of the United Nations Kofi Annan, have been named in
association with the Panama Papers.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2013, wealth distribution in Ghanaian society was highly unequal, with a majority of wealth held by the top 20% of the population.
• Ghana's judicial system is tasked with addressing issues related to corruption, economic malpractice, and lack of economic transparency.
• Despite notable economic progress, Ghana continues to face significant obstacles, including the need for reform in specific institutions and improvements in property rights.
• The overall investment environment in Ghana is hindered by a lack of market transparency, which poses challenges to sustained economic growth.
• Addressing institutional reforms, property rights, and enhancing market transparency are essential steps for Ghana to maintain its rapid economic growth trajectory.

• The index score reflects perceived levels of corruption within Ghana's public sector.

• Notable individuals associated with Ghana and linked to the Panama Papers include John Addo Kufuor, son of former President John Agyekum Kufuor, and Kojo Annan, son of former United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan.

The Centre for Scientific Research into Plant Medicine is an agency of the
Ministry of Health that was set up in the 1970s for research and development
and as a practical resource (product production & distribution/provision)
primarily in areas of biotechnology related to medicinal plants. This includes
both herbal medicine and work on more advanced applications. It also has a
secondary role as an educational resource for foreign students in health,
biotechnology and related fields.
openai_summarised_points: • The Centre for Scientific Research into Plant Medicine is an agency under the Ghanaian Ministry of Health.
• It was established in the 1970s with the primary purpose of conducting research and development in the field of plant medicine.
• The agency serves as a practical resource for the production, distribution, and provision of products related to plant-based medicine.
• Its focus includes biotechnology applications related to medicinal plants, encompassing both herbal medicine and more advanced biotechnological research.
• The Centre also functions as an educational resource, particularly for foreign students studying health, biotechnology, and related disciplines.

The use of computer technology for teaching and learning began to receive
government of Ghana's attention from the late 1990s. The information and
communications technology in education policy of Ghana requires the use of
information and communications technology for teaching and learning at all
levels of education. The Ministry of Education supports institutions in
teaching of information and communications technology literacy. The majority
of secondary, and some basic schools of Ghana have computer laboratories.

Ghana's intention to become the information technology hub of West Africa has
led the government of Ghana to enact cyber crime legislation and enhance cyber
security practices. Acting on that goal, in 2008 Ghana passed the _Electronic
Communications Act_ and the _Electronic Transactions Act_ , which established
the legal framework for governing information technology. In November 2011,
the Deputy Minister for Communications and Technology announced the
development of a national cyber security strategy, aimed at combating cyber
crime and securing critical infrastructure.

In June 2012, the National Information Technology Agency announced a national
computer emergency response team "strategy" designed to co-ordinate government
response to cyber-attacks, both internal and external. The agency also
established computer emergency response teams for each municipal,
metropolitan, and district assembly to improve co-ordination and information-
sharing on cyberspace threats. Ghana is ranked 2nd in Africa and 7th globally
in cyber warfare, cyber-terrorism, cyber crime, and internet crime. In 2018,
the National Cyber Security Centre was founded. It is the national agency
responsible for cybersecurity. In November 2020, Parliament passed the
Cybersecurity Act 2020. The Minister for Communications, Ursula Owusu-Ekuful,
indicated that, "a successful economy is hinged on a secured, safe and
resilient national digital ecosystem. Cyber-security is, therefore, very
critical to the economic development of the country and essential to the
protection of the rights of individuals within the national digital
ecosystem".
openai_summarised_points: • The use of computer technology for teaching and learning in Ghana began to attract government attention from the late 1990s.
• Ghana's "Information and Communications Technology in Education" policy mandates the integration of ICT for teaching and learning at all educational levels.
• The Ministry of Education actively supports educational institutions in developing ICT literacy.
• Most secondary schools and some basic schools in Ghana have established computer laboratories to facilitate ICT education.
• Ghana aims to become the leading information technology hub in West Africa, prompting legislative and strategic actions in cybersecurity.
• In 2008, Ghana enacted the _Electronic Communications Act_ and the _Electronic Transactions Act_, creating the legal framework for governing information technology and cyber activities.

• In November 2011, the Deputy Minister for Communications and Technology announced the development of a national cybersecurity strategy focused on combating cybercrime and protecting critical infrastructure.

• The National Information Technology Agency (NITA) announced in June 2012 a national computer emergency response team (CERT) strategy to coordinate government responses to cyber-attacks, both internal and external.
• NITA also established CERTs for each municipal, metropolitan, and district assembly to enhance coordination and information sharing regarding cyberspace threats.
• Ghana is ranked 2nd in Africa and 7th globally in the domains of cyber warfare, cyber-terrorism, cybercrime, and internet crime.
• The National Cyber Security Centre was established in 2018 as Ghana’s primary agency responsible for cybersecurity.
• In November 2020, Ghana's Parliament passed the Cybersecurity Act 2020 to strengthen national cybersecurity measures.

• Ursula Owusu-Ekuful, the Minister for Communications, emphasized that a successful economy depends on a secure, safe, and resilient digital ecosystem, highlighting cybersecurity as critical to economic development and the protection of individual rights within the digital space.

A villa in East Ridge

The real estate and housing market has become an important and strategic
economic sector, particularly in the urban centres of south Ghana such as
Accra, Kumasi, Sekondi-Takoradi and Tema. However, many of its citizens
particularly those in Accra cannot afford the housing prices which is a trait
of most major cities globally particularly in the West. Kumasi is growing at a
faster rate than Accra, and there is less competition in its real estate
market. The gross rental income tax of Ghana is withheld at 10%, capital gains
are taxed at 15% with a 5% gift tax imposed on the transfer of properties and
Ghana's real estate market is divided into 3 areas: public sector real estate
development, emerging private sector real estate development, and private
individuals. The activities of these 3 groups are facilitated by the Ghanaian
banks and the primary mortgage market which has demonstrated enormous growth
potential. Recent developments have given birth to a boom in the construction
sector, including the housing and public housing sector generating and
injecting billions of dollars annually into the Ghanaian economy. The real
estate market investment perspective and attraction comes from Ghana's
tropical location and robust political stability. An increasing number of the
Ghanaian populace are investing in properties, and the Ghana government is
empowering the private sector in the real estate direction.

In July 2013, International Enterprise Singapore a global office in Accra to
develop trade and investment on logistics, oil and gas, aviation,
transportation and consumer sectors. Singapore and Ghana also signed four
bilateral agreements to promote public sector and private sector
collaboration, as Ghana aims to predominantly shift its economic trade
partnership to East Asia and Southeast Asia. The economic centre is IE
Singapore's second office in Africa. Ghana's labour force in 2008 totalled
11.5 million Ghanaian citizens. Tema Harbour is Africa's largest manmade
harbour, and Takoradi Harbour along with Tema harbour handle goods and
exports. They are also traffic junctions where goods are transhipped; the Tema
harbour handles the majority of the nation's export cargo and most of the
country's chief exports is shipped from Takoradi harbour. The Takoradi harbour
and Tema harbour are operated by the state-owned Ghana Ports and Harbours
Authority.

Bank of Ghana

Over the years, the country has encountered various economic challenges
especially in its bid to become financially sustainable. One of the most
prominent has been high public debt. In January 2023, the Bank of Ghana
reported that the country's level of debt was up to the tune of GH¢575.7
billion at the end of November 2022.

The 2010 United States Department of Labor estimated over 2.7 million child
laborers in Ghana, or about 43% of all children aged 5–14. 78.7% of these
children work in agriculture, 17.6% in fishing and transportation services,
and 3.7% in industry, which includes manufacturing work and mining. In Ghana
64% of children seek work for financial reasons, making it the leading driver
for child labor in the region. Most children working in rural areas are
working on family farms and often combine schooling with their work. In Urban
areas, such as Accra and Ashanti children are often not enrolled in school and
are often engaged in artisanal fishing and domestic services. Child porters,
locally called _kayaye_ , work in urban areas and some of them are as young as
6 years.

A young 'kayaye' girl engaged in selling palm wine in Ghana

Agriculture, fishing and artisan mining were the largest employers.

In southern Volta region, children work in religious servitude for a period
ranging between few months to three years. They are known as _trokosi_
(literally: wife of a god), _fiashidi_ , or _vudusi_. This practice requires
young girls to work and serve the religious order, in order to atone for
family members’ alleged sins or as an offering for the family's good fortune.
This practice is claimed to be also present in neighboring countries, even
though it has been outlawed and carries a prison term under the laws of Ghana
and neighboring countries.

In 2013, statistics on children's work have not changed much and according to
the DOL's _Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor_ in Ghana, the majority
of working children engage in hazardous activities like pesticide spraying in
the production of cocoa, fishing and gold mining. The Department's 2014 _List
of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor_ includes fish and tilapia in
particular, cocoa and gold as goods produced in such working conditions in
Ghana.
